awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   The Size of the Global Dust Cycle and its Radiative Impact on Climate
awd_abstract_narration:
At any given time, the Earth's atmosphere contains tens of millions of metric tons of desert dust. Surprisingly, many basic questions regarding the effects of these vast quantities of dust on climate remain poorly known. How much dust is actually in the atmosphere? Does desert dust warm or cool our planet? Will future climate-induced changes in dust storms oppose or enhance man-made climate changes? This project will address these fundamental questions by leveraging satellite observations, experimental measurements of atmospheric dust and its properties, and climate model simulations of desert dust climate impacts. In addition, this project will integrate educational and research activities at UCLA's department of Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences through the establishment of a Research-Enhanced Learning Assistant program.

The research will lead to improved understanding of desert dust's prevalence and its climate impacts as well as enhance forecasts of regional and global climate changes, thereby helping to inform policies to adapt to or mitigate future climate changes. Furthermore, the project results will facilitate improved understanding of dust impacts on weather, the biosphere, air quality, and human health. Finally, the Research-Enhanced Learning Assistant program will improve learning, recruitment, and retention of geosciences students, and especially of under-represented minorities.

por.por_cntn:
At any given time, our atmosphere contains tens of millions of metric tons of desert dust. Surprisingly, many basic questions regarding the effects of these vast quantities of dust on climate remain poorly known. How much dust is actually in the atmosphere? Does desert dust warm or cool our planet? Will future climate-induced changes in dust storms oppose or enhance man-made climate changes? This project addressed these fundamental questions by leveraging satellite observations, experimental measurements of atmospheric dust and its properties, and climate model simulations of desert dust climate impacts.

This grant's contributions to intellectual merit include the following:

1. Showing that climate models overestimate fine dust, which cools, yet miss most of the atmosphere's coarse dust, which warms and surprisingly accounts for a third of all particulate matter by mass. Consequently, dust has less of a cooling effect on climate than previously thought.

2. Producing the first quantification of the feedback that predicted future changes in dust loading will have on climate change. We calculated that for every degree Celsius that the planet warms, this feedback will perturb the Earth's energy balance by between -0.04 to +0.02 Watts per square meter.

3. Determining that the atmosphere contains between ~22 to 29 million metric tons of dust. We also constrained the distribution of that dust in space and time and determined the contribution of each the world's major source regions (e.g., East Asia, Australia, the Sahara, the Sahel, the Middle East, etc) to this global dust loading.

This grant's contributions to broader impacts include the following:

1. Establishing a successful yearly outreach program to underserved Los Angeles high schools (see https://serc.carleton.edu/teachearth/activities/212028.html)

2. Introducing undergraduate 'learning assistants' (LAs) in several atmospheric sciences classes (~200 students/year), thereby increasing learning and retention, especially for underrepresented students.

3. Funding a pedagogy seminar for LAs, which contributed to the LA program's rapid spread across UCLA as a now institutionalized program that supports ~10,000 enrolled students per quarter. See https://ceils.ucla.edu/learningassistants/

4. Developing a required sophomore-level undergraduate research class that has contributed to a large increase in research participation in UCLA's Atmospheric & Oceanic Sciences department.

5. The training of scientists from various backgrounds, including eight undergraduates (seven female) that went on to strong graduate programs; a female graduate student who went on to a prestigious postdoctoral fellowship position; and a Black postdoctoral fellow, who is now a faculty member at a research university.

6. Producing a more accurate quantification of dust effects on climate, which has been included in the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change's Sixth Assessment Report, which informs world climate policy.


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Jasper F Kok
